gt

Source: vignettes/gt.Rmd
gt.Rmd

This vignette shows you how to use palettes to colour data cells with gt.

library(palettes)
library(gt)
library(scales)
library(dplyr)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

Preparing the table

To demonstrate how to use palettes to colour data cells with gt, we will use airquality as an input data table with the following columns:

  • Year, Month, Day: the numeric month and day of month for the record
  • Temp: maximum daily air temperature in degrees Fahrenheit (°F)

Temperature is a good fit for colour—we can represent cold with blue, hot with red, and white as a midpoint.

First we create the gt table we will add colour to. The table is slightly modified from a table in the Introduction to Creating gt Tables article. It looks like this.

# Modify the `airquality` dataset by adding the year
# of the measurements (1973) and limiting to 10 rows
airquality_m <- 
  airquality %>%
  mutate(Year = 1973L) %>%
  slice(1:10) %>% 
  select(Year, Month, Day, Temp)
  
# Create a display table using the `airquality`
# dataset; arrange columns into groups
gt_tbl <- 
  gt(airquality_m) %>%
  tab_header(
    title = "New York Temperature Measurements",
    subtitle = "Daily measurements in New York City (May 1-10, 1973)"
  ) %>%
  tab_spanner(
    label = "Time",
    columns = c(Year, Month, Day)
  ) %>%
  tab_spanner(
    label = "Measurement",
    columns = c(Temp)
  ) %>%
  cols_label(
    Temp = html("Temp,<br>&deg;F")
  )

# Show the gt table
gt_tbl
New York Temperature Measurements
Daily measurements in New York City (May 1-10, 1973)
Time Measurement
Year Month Day Temp,
°F
1973 5 1 67
1973 5 2 72
1973 5 3 74
1973 5 4 62
1973 5 5 56
1973 5 6 66
1973 5 7 65
1973 5 8 59
1973 5 9 61
1973 5 10 69

Adding colour

We can use the Benedictus palette for blue, white, and red with some minor modifications.

colour_vector <- pal_brewer(met_palettes$Benedictus, n = 3, direction = -1)
colour_vector
#> <palettes_colour[3]>
#> • #19318B
#> • #FFFFFF
#> • #99133D

At the moment, objects of class palettes_palette or palettes_colour cannot be used directly with the colour functions in gt. To work around this we cast the colour vector to a character vector.

character_vector <- as.character(colour_vector)
character_vector
#> [1] "#19318B" "#FFFFFF" "#99133D"

Now we can use gt::data_color() to colour the temperature cells. The colors argument accepts either a colour mapping function from the scales package or a vector of colours to use for each distinct value or level in each of the provided columns as input. Both of these input types are compatible with the colour specifications used by palettes.

Here we pass the character vector directly to the colors argument.

gt_tbl %>% 
  data_color(
    columns = Temp,
    colors  = character_vector
  )
New York Temperature Measurements
Daily measurements in New York City (May 1-10, 1973)
Time Measurement
Year Month Day Temp,
°F
1973 5 1 67
1973 5 2 72
1973 5 3 74
1973 5 4 62
1973 5 5 56
1973 5 6 66
1973 5 7 65
1973 5 8 59
1973 5 9 61
1973 5 10 69

But this works equally well with the colour mapping functions from the scales package.

gt_tbl %>% 
  data_color(
    columns = Temp,
    colors  = col_numeric(character_vector, domain = c(56, 74))
  )
New York Temperature Measurements
Daily measurements in New York City (May 1-10, 1973)
Time Measurement
Year Month Day Temp,
°F
1973 5 1 67
1973 5 2 72
1973 5 3 74
1973 5 4 62
1973 5 5 56
1973 5 6 66
1973 5 7 65
1973 5 8 59
1973 5 9 61
1973 5 10 69
